p.s: In the given exerptexcerpt from the play The Merchant of Venice written by William Shakespeare Shylock is characterized directly and indirectly on many different occasions.
To start off one can say that Shylock is a Jew.
This becomes clear to the audience when Shylock speaks of their synagogue with his friend Tubal (l. 30).
Also one of Shylock's main character traits is that he loves money.

He does that maybe even more than he loves his daughter because after Tubal tells him that he cant find his daughter, Shylock mentions his money and his jewels that his daughter took, before mentioning her (ll. 3-5).
That makes the audience think that Shylock is more angry and worried about him losing money and jewels than aobut losing his daughter, which makes him unsympathetic.
This love for materialistic things is underlined by an alliteration in line 5: ... and other precious, precious jewels.
This makes Shylock seem like he loves money.
Shylock can also be described as very angry and hectic.

This is made clear by a repititionrepetition / alliteration in line 3: Why, there, there, there, there! This underlines the said character trait and gives the audience an example of how Shylock reacts to bad news: he gets angry and hectic.
Shylock can also be characterized as thinking of himself as being very unlucky because in line 9 he says that there is no bad luck that won't land on my shoulders (l. 9).
This sentence can be seen as a stylistic device at the same time because there are two nos in it.
This makes Shylock seem even more unlucky than he is to the audience.
In addition to loving money more than his daughter, one can also say that he doesn't even love his daughter or even hates her.
The audience could interpet it in that way because Shylock wishes that his daughter was dead twice in one monologue (l. 5-7).
This makes him even more unsympathetic to the audience than any of the other aspects.
Shylock is also a very gleeful person because he is joyful after Tubal tells him that AntoniosAntonio's ships have gone missing: I thank god, I thank god (l. 14).
This is again a repititionrepetition and not a vey positive character trait which makes him unlikable for the audience.
Another one of Shylock's character traits is that he has mood swings.
This happens throughout the entire conversation with Tubal and can be happening because of the different news he receives.
This makes him seem indecisive and unstable to the audience.
Shylock is also very hungry for revenge against Antonio which can also be seen in his positive reaction to the bad news for Antonio (l. 14).
This revenge can be traced back to Antonio abusing and insulting Shylock his entire life.
This makes Shylock seem more human but could also make him seem as villanous depending on what perspective one sees it from.
This is again made clear in line 27: I will have the heart of him.
This could also be seen as a metaphor for not only killing Antonio but also for taking his spirit and his will so Shylock can be satisfied after all he had to endure.
In addition to being hungry for revenge, Shylock is also very violent and brutal because he wants to torture and plague Antonio (l. 22).
In the same line there is an anaphora which underlines the said character traits: ... I'll plague him; I'll torture him (l. 22).
The last character trait one can take away from the given excerpt is that Shylock exploits his friends.
He for example sends Tubal to look afer his daughter instead of doing it himself (l. 1) and orders Tubal to hire an officer for him instead of doing it himself: Go Tubal , fee me an officer (l. 27).
This makes Shylock seem very commanding and unthankful to the audience.
The use of language in Generalgeneral is very old fashioned due to the time the play as written in: Thou tortourest me ... (l. 24).
This could be difficult for audiences today but was no problem at the time the play was written.
Shylock also speaks in blanc verse which was typical for villains at that time.
This can be seen in his monologue from lines 3 to 10.
This makes the audience think of him as the villain of the story.
All in all one can say that most of the character traits that can be detected in this excerpt are rather negative and make Shylock seem unsympathetic and abd in general to the audience.
This is also underlined by many repetitions and other stylistic devices such as anaphoras.
